title: Upper Limb Anatomy and Surgical Intervention
content: The upper limb includes the elbow, shoulder, hand, and wrist, with nerves located throughout. Understanding the structure and anatomy of these parts can help identify causes of pain and injury, and determine when surgical intervention may be necessary. Surgeons often rely on MRI imaging, but the physical exam and symptoms usually matter more than what the image shows. Self-examination can also help understand if a feeling is problematic or likely to improve over time.

title: Orthopedic Surgery and Specialization
content: Orthopedics is a broad field that is also highly specialized. There has been a knowledge explosion in the past two decades in terms of research and new science. There are subsets of orthopedics and then there are subsets of shoulder surgery that involves just research versus just clinical practice. Fellowships are almost mandatory because you need to have a special interest because the groups you’d apply to work for want you to have some subspeciality.

title: Evolution of Orthopedics and Recent Advances
content: Minimally invasive orthopedic surgery has become common for joints. Knee arthroscopy was the first big arthroscopic realm to develop. Shoulder arthroscopy was primitive by the time Alton was in residency. They had the basic equipment to get into the shoulder, but they couldn’t do much. Today, we’ve gone from purely metal to now often purely braided polyester as an anchor device. This is super cool because there’s no metal in your body. And the transition through that was plastic.

title: Anatomy of the Upper Extremities
content: To understand and appreciate the complexity of the upper extremity, you have to appreciate what we did during evolution. When we stood up, that became an enormous force multiplier. But you pay a price for it, which is stability. We paid an enormous price in these joints, not as strong, not as stable. When we went from the ball on socket joints or the very stable, simple hinge joints to these cup and saucer type joints (specifically the shoulder, which is intrinsically very unstable). Our opposable thumb at the basal joint is terribly unstable.

title: Understanding Ligaments and Tendons
content: Tendons are the connective tissue that connects muscle to bone. Ligaments are connective tissue that connect bone to bone. Labrum is kind of its own entity. It has a transition zone between fibrous tissue to osseous bony tissue. It’s a fibro-osseous structure.

title: Rotator Cuff Muscles
content: The rotator cuff is made up of four muscles: the supraspinatus, the subscapularis, the infraspinatus, and the teres minor. The supraspinatus is the primary muscle that initiates elevation of the shoulders. The infraspinatus, and the teres minor are on the backside of the joint. They are very important as the external rotators. They give a lot of stability to the shoulder, whether you’re playing golf or lifting weights.

title: Supraspinatus Tendon Tear
content: A tear in the supraspinatus tendon can have physiologic downsides due to its location. It can be rung out and it doesn’t have a great blood supply. The key is it gets where the tendon tears most of the time. And that is the part that attaches to the bone, and it gets blood supply from that bone. Surgically, the goal is to get that reattached to that bone so it can get all of those growth factors and that new healing back.

title: Rotator Cuff Injuries
content: When a person “tears their rotator cuff,” that can be a very heterogeneous diagnosis. Technically it could apply to a tear in any of those 4 muscles. Or a tear in the junction between the muscle and tendon. Or a complete separation of the tendon from the osseous structure of the bone. Tears are broadly classified into degenerative tears and traumatic tears.

title: Shoulder Joint Dislocation
content: Shoulder joint dislocation can be caused by a violent injury. It’s most often associated with the dislocation (subluxation of the shoulder). Technically a subluxation is an incomplete dislocation; it’s the shoulder coming out, but it pops back in easily. A dislocation is where the shoulder comes out and it needs to be put back in. The more dislocations (or subluxations) one has, the more stretchy and compliant the tissues become.

title: Stability of the Shoulder Joint
content: The shoulder joint gets a lot of static stability from the superior, inferior, anterior, and posterior labrum. If you have someone who has a pretty stable joint and then they sublux, the only way you can do that is by tearing the ligaments, but usually you also tear/ separate the labrum from its hard, bony cartilaginous, perfectly fused attachment.

title: SLAP Tear
content: When you’re referring to a SLAP tear, SLAP stands for superior labral anterior posterior. That is on the top side of the diagram. SLAP tears are not clinically relevant for everybody. They are relevant for younger, very athletic people (overhead athletes, weightlifters, people doing CrossFit, people doing all manner of more aggressive sports).

title: Dynamic and Static Stabilizers
content: Dynamic stabilizers can compensate for the loss of static stabilizers but they will fatigue, leading to problems. When you are maxing out and doing it repetitively, the dynamic stabilizers fatigue. Fatigue is a problem. If they have a weekend-long match (8 events in 3 days), they are fine the 1st 2 days, but by the 3rd day, they are fatigued and then they start subluxing. Then they get all this secondary inflammation and pain and that’s when the damage occurs and they have to sit out. Then we have to strengthen rehab, sometimes even tighten up the capsule when they get so loose.

title: Biceps Tendon and Common Injuries
content: The biceps tendon can be incredibly painful (tendonosis). The biceps is 1 muscle in our arm, but it’s 2 tendons at the origin in the shoulder. It has a single point of attachment in the forearm, crosses the joint as 1 muscle and then splits into 2 bellies with 2 attachment points. The long head is the one that often gets inflamed. It can be quite painful and can affect everyday life. People often do tear this biceps due to wear and tear or acute trauma. It leads to a classic Popeye muscle where half their muscle is balled up and looks weird. It’s not really that much of a functional consequence. Usually it stops hurting when it ruptures.

title: Labrum Tears and Natural Loss of Cartilage
content: The labrum will naturally degenerate just by using it, so will the cartilage. We know there’s a genetic predisposition to arthritis. By arthritis, it means not just inflammation of the joint, but a true loss of the cartilage integrity. For younger athletic people, who have a humeral head that’s been damaged and they have a big chunk, maybe a quarter size (maybe a 50 cent piece size) of full cartilage loss, that’s not great. That just keeps sloughing off cartilage and keeps getting inflamed. They’re on the young side so you don’t want to do a shoulder replacement on them. Instead, they will do a humeral head resurfacing (a nice, new, smooth metal head), but they leave the glenoid intact and they have good cartilage there.

title: Shoulder Evaluation and When to Have Surgery
content: It’s important to get a good history of the mechanics of the injury. You need to know a combination of the mechanism of injury, the symptoms, and the physical exam, and if you do those compulsively and well, you will be 95% accurate without any MRI. Pain shouldn’t be the only symptom we look for‒ we have to look for function. If someone came in with a traumatic motor vehicle accident where they tore their rotator cuff badly at age 60, 65. Alton would tell them it’s not necessary to have them repaired. But if you don’t repair it, those muscles that lost their muscle-tendon connection are going to atrophy. It may not be painful, but if you want to do things you were doing before the accident, they need to be repaired.

title: Understanding the Acromion and Bursa
content: The acromion is a bony structure under which the rotator cuff glides. Any place in our body that there’s two structures, anatomically in the limbs that move differentially with one another, there’s usually a bursa that forms in between. That bursa is just a thin filmy structure that can thicken up and become very inflamed and become bursitis, which is very painful. Otherwise, the purpose of the bursa is to allow these things to glide past each other frictionless.

title: Types of Acromion and Their Impact
content: Some of us are born with an extra kind of downsloping of that acromion, or a bone spur, or we acquire it from repetitive athletic use. You can have a type I, a type II, or a type III acromion. Type I is totally flat (this is the majority of people). Type II is the second most common. Type III predisposes you to this problem (about 30% of people have this type). You’re only at risk if you are an overhead athlete, lift weights overhead or do aggressive things. If you’re sedentary and never exercise, you’ll never have a problem because you’re not repetitively loading it enough to wear it down or cause a tear.

title: Screening for Anatomical Predispositions to Injury
content: It would be interesting if we knew these things in advance and we could maybe modify and temper our activity around our genetics effectively. If you have a congenitally narrow stenotic spine and you’re playing football, you’re way more at risk for catastrophic spinal cord injury. But if you have your first stinger, then you need to be screened, and see if you are at high risk. If you are, then you have a very serious discussion about what you’re subjecting your neck to.

title: Pain Generators in the Shoulder
content: A type III acromion can be a pain generator. The AC joint is another one. Almost everybody through wear and tear, middle age and beyond, has arthritis in the AC joint… it’s almost always asymptomatic, but it can be symptomatic. Young weightlifters can develop fluid in the end of the clavicle from repetitive use. Repetitive jamming or bruising of the bone and cartilage causes the cartilage to disintegrate and the bone to lose its integrity. It starts to get very soft and it gets very inflamed. As soon as you start breaking up cartilage, all the macrophages from the body come in there and then you get a big inflammatory response. You get a lot of extra fluid and a lot of pain.

title: The Nuance of the Shoulder Exam
content: There will never be a substitute for the nuance of the exam and the history of the injury and of what causes pain. You get pinpoint diagnoses with the various tests. There are plenty of things you find with tests that aren’t symptomatic. But our patients need us to be able to still diagnose, listen to them, hear what they’re saying. You want to hear the patient’s story and know what’s really going on to determine whether they need surgical or non-surgical care or what kind of care they need.

title: Frozen Shoulder
content: Shoulder pain can have many causes.

title: Common Shoulder Problems
content: The AC joint can be the problem. Other issues can include Bursitis, a rotator cuff injury, a labral injury, Bicep tendon inflammation, Arthritis, Adhesive capsulitis, and Neck pain from the spine.

title: Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)
content: Frozen shoulder is the layman term for adhesive capsulitis. This is very common, and it can conflate all sorts of diagnoses. It’s worse if you have diabetes. There’s a lot of misinformation about it because the old literature says it will get better with time, which is not true. Only about 1 out of 5 patients actually ever need surgery, and surgery is never the first option. Surgery would be a simple, 30-minute release of the capsule and reduction of the inflammation. 80% do not need surgery, they need some way to control the inflammation along with really good physical therapy and a home program to restore mobility.

title: Treatment for Frozen Shoulder
content: Frozen shoulder can respond to NSAIDs. However, NSAIDs aren’t strong enough. A small dose of cortisone into the joint 1 time can be more effective. This treatment can provide dramatic relief from such a simple treatment. Physical therapy is still needed after the cortisone injection.

title: Shoulder Pain Originating from the Neck
content: A big source of shoulder pain is referred pain from the neck. People will come in with shoulder pain going down their arm, maybe even down to their hand. The pain is not coming from their shoulder, it’s coming from their neck.

title: Surgical Treatments for a Labral Tear
content: The approach for repairing a SLAP tear is similar to that of a complete labral tear. The largest incisions are 1-1.5 cm. The others are small percutaneous holes to put cannulas in and then drill through. It takes 10 minutes to do each anchor. The exam under anesthesia is crucial for a dynamic exam. The patient’s muscles have very little effect. The surgeon tests the static stabilizers. In addition to just repairing the labrum itself, the surgeon needs to gather up some of the capsule (which has become too capacious), and do what we call a capsulorrhaphy (which is to gather and tighten that up too).

title: Caveat about Unnecessary Surgery
content: Unnecessary surgery can lead to complications. For example, a professional violinist in her early 60s who had shoulder pain had a labral repair and ended up with the stiffest shoulder. The surgery was the exact opposite; it produced a complete tightening of the capsule. The surgeon had to go in and scope her, release everything that had been done and release the capsule that was all crunched up and tightened up. He even had to take some of the sutures out to free up her shoulder.

title: Age Factor in Decision to Operate
content: Age factors into the decision to operate. Some people thought it was crazy to have a labral repair at age 50. But without the surgery, there was the inevitability of having a shoulder replacement in another 10 years. People now are so much younger physiologically (in better condition). A 50-year-old now cannot be compared to data of 50-year-olds 20 years ago. The decision is based on biological age, not chronological age.

title: Scope Imaging and Surgical Repair
content: Sometimes they have better cartilage than what the MRI is indicating and he can go ahead and do a repair. The biggest ports are for the camera, and there are a few working ports in the front and back. Pathology is superior and anterior. They have 2 different kinds of angled lenses, so they can see around corners if needed. He can see the superior labrum; he can see the biceps. Yes, you’re shooting carbon dioxide to blow everything up. And he uses water to do the same thing, but not at high pressure (35 mmHg). It makes the capsule bigger. Lower pressure means less postoperative pain and less distention. You can still put in little retractors, kind of pull tissue out of the way and so forth. Usually you need 2 working portals in the front. Which are just basically canals to get in with instruments, that are long enough to fit through and do the work.

title: Surgical Repair Process
content: You drill a little hole in the glenoid fossa. The diameter depends on what kind of anchor you are doing. Usually not more than 3 mm, and now we’re down to 1.8 mm. 3 mm seems big, but that’s what you fit the plastic or the absorbable anchor in that you tap in with the mallet. You’re drilling into the bone, and you have to get the angle right. And then the anchor inserts through that. They’re not circumferential, they’re straight in. If we did them open as we used to, we’d drill holes and use a suture going through circumferentially.

title: Anchor Insertion
content: What holds the anchor in? Is it the pressure of putting in an anchor that is bigger than the hole? Yes. Historically there were some that we screw in, but not anymore. Now they are purely basically braided polyester. The suture goes in, and then as you carefully pull it back out, the way they’re designed, they ball up. It’s super strong; you can lift the shoulder off the table. It would take fully traumatic force to dislodge it.

title: Joint Examination
content: Do you examine the cuff while you’re in there? Absolutely, he goes through and does a survey of the joint. He looks at the cartilage surfaces, all the nooks and crannies. He looks at the rotator cuff inserting on the bone, from inside out. And you can see if it’s smooth, if it’s frayed. If it’s notably frayed, you can probe it. Occasionally he may see a small, almost full-thickness tear (because they’re athletes). Then I might put a stitch or two in that to fix that. You look at the biceps. You can pull the biceps into the joint and see a pretty good segment of it and see if it’s inflamed, torn, something abnormal there. You can see the tendon of the biceps really well too, and if it’s frayed.

title: Inflammation and Pain Management
content: Inflammation shows up as really red. Alton likes to get a little electrocautery wand, and he paints the internal and gets rid of all that pink because it’s inflammatory. It hurts, and that’s part of one of the big pain generators. Now, theoretically, if you fix everything, that’s going to go away anyway. But it helps patients early post-op.

title: Rotator Cuff Repair
content: What is the most common athlete’s tear to the rotator cuff? It depends on if they’re an overhead athlete. In that case, the supraspinatus is usually torn. Sometimes it can be the infraspinatus. If a guy has a straight-up supraspinatus tear, do you even need to enter the capsule necessarily, depending on how close it is? You do, you need to make sure that you’re not missing anything, which is common in the athletes. There are a couple of interesting variations.

title: Tommy John Surgery
content: Where does the Tommy John surgery fit into this? That’s the elbow. It fits in because a lot of people add torque on their elbow because they have shoulder pathology. If they have a little weakness or something going on in their shoulder, they will overthrow with their forearm and their flexor-pronator mass. They’ll overthrow with the torque, and then they’ll tear their medial collateral ligament of their elbow. And vice versa, if they have a partially torn medial collateral ligament that hasn’t yet been identified, they can overthrow with their shoulder to compensate, to get more angular velocity on that, because they can’t muster it through the elbow.

title: Athlete's Career and Shoulder Injury
content: How many years ago would it have been the case that a torn rotator cuff was the end of a pitcher’s career or a quarterback’s career at the professional level? Probably 15. But not today. Peter can’t think of anything that could be more stressful, “throwing a baseball seems even more stressful than throwing a football because you do it more times in a game” and Alton agrees. What has changed is earlier diagnosis. Now at the Division 1 collegiate level, any pain is almost over-evaluated.

title: Understanding and Treating Shoulder Tears
content: Repairing small tears before they become bigger depends on the individual case. Sometimes it’s not the tear that causes symptoms but inflammation related to it. Full-thickness tears can be minimally symptomatic while partial-thickness tears can be very symptomatic. The size of the tear can vary depending on the size of the patient. A full-thickness tear refers to the depth of the tear. If half the tendon is torn, it can significantly affect the biomechanics of a high-level throwing athlete and cannot be ignored. However, a partial-thickness tear off the tendon could be ignored. In some cases, strong athletes may experience a wrenching injury, causing an interstitial tear at the musculotendinous junction. This can result in a tremendous amount of edema, weakness, pain, but it can heal without any intervention with just some anti-inflammatory and time to heal.

title: Role of Platelet-Rich Plasma (PRP) Injections and Stem Cells in Healing Tears
content: Stem cells may not replace a labrum, but they can be valuable if there is a tear in the muscle. However, there are a lot of poorly designed studies being used to justify using stem cells or PRP, so one has to be careful to extrapolate it to individual practice. There are anecdotal reports where people say there was a tear on the MRI, they injected PRP and it’s healed, gone. However, there is not enough data to support benefits from PRP injection. The only downside sometimes seen is more flare reactions from PRP injected into tennis elbow, where people are really painful for a couple of weeks.

title: Repair of an AC Joint Separation
content: AC separations are common injuries. If you fall hard and sprain your AC joint, it can be a type I injury where you stretch a little bit and injure the ligaments. It doesn’t look any different on x-ray and generally, they go away. A grade II is where you’ve clearly torn the AC ligaments and it’s up by about 30%. This could be a partial or complete tear, but it just didn’t distort it too much. Almost all those can be treated nonoperatively. Grade III is where it’s completely up. If it’s up to 30% widening, increase in that space, then that’s the grade II. If it’s 100% or more, then that’s a grade III. The vast majority of the operative ones are in the III category. Asymmetry won’t have a functional impairment, generally speaking, except if you’re doing certain exercises.

title: Orthopedic Surgery: Clavicle and Coracoid Drilling
content: This involves drilling through the clavicle and coracoid, and passing a heavy polyester suture through. The suture is pulled down and tied over, resulting in a rock solid structure. The torn ligaments are brought into continuity again to allow for healing. The polymer used in the suture is not biodegradable and will stay in place forever. Patients are advised not to return to regular activity for at least 3-4 weeks, and by 6 weeks, the structure is usually pretty strong.

title: Emergency Orthopedic Surgery: Clavicle and Mediastinum Separation
content: Clavicle and mediastinum separation is not common but can be very problematic. This condition often requires immediate surgery. The sternoclavicular joints can be felt at the base of the clavicle. Damage to this joint is not common, but it's not rare either. In some cases, the joint can displace behind the manubrium, where a major vein lives, posing a life-threatening risk.

title: Shoulder Replacement Surgery
content: Shoulder replacement surgery has evolved significantly over the years. It is now an outpatient procedure unless the patient has comorbidities. The procedure is usually indicated for patients who have worn down the cartilage completely, causing pain and dysfunction. The surgery involves the use of implants and is performed through a small anterior incision. The arthritic head of the humerus is removed, the glenoid is reamed down, and a high density polyethylene socket is inserted. The rotator cuff remains intact throughout the procedure.

title: Post-Shoulder Replacement Surgery Limitations
content: A year after shoulder replacement surgery, patients are generally not limited in their activities except for heavy weights. They can play catch, tennis, golf, shoot basketball, and swim. However, they are advised against doing bench press or Iron Cross type activities.

title: Elbow Anatomy
content: The humerus bone is the arm bone coming down.

title: Elbow Anatomy and Common Injuries
content: The elbow is a stable, undulating structure, different from the shoulder. It consists of the radial head, which is the rotating bone of the forearm, and the ulna, which is the fixed straight bone of the forearm. The tendons that go down to the forearm and to the hand originate above the joint. In tennis elbow, a tear occurs on the radial collateral ligaments. On the inside of the elbow, where our funny bone nerve is, the funny bone nerve is the ulnar nerve. Overlying that is the muscles, the flexor pronator muscles, that helps bend the elbow and pronate the forearm. These can tear in this region, leading to golfer’s elbow (medial epicondylitis) or tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis). Another common tendon injury occurs to the biceps tendon. There is a bursa that lives over the tip of our elbow, which can get the big golf ball size filling of fluid (olecranon bursitis).

title: Elbow Health and Injury Prevention
content: The elbow is a very finicky joint. If you don’t get those things perfect when you fix them, they can quickly lead to arthritis. Even the subtle fracture patterns that happen and aren’t seen or appreciated, can lead to rapid destruction of the joint. Use patterns are significant for that. The reason the lateral was historically associated and called tennis elbow is because of one-handed back hands. It’s a much less mechanically sound. And we have less strength with our external rotators than we have with our pectoralis and our subscapularis for forehand shots, so it’s under more stress. You can get them at any age. Alton treats a lot of people age 40-60. And now that’s creeping up to the 70’s.

title: Elbow Pain Treatment
content: The first line of treatment is always rest, good stretching, and usually NSAIDs by mouth. Rarely does he use physical therapy for these formally, because it’s just not much to do. Sometimes they’re very painful. Some people wake up in the morning, they can’t even straighten their elbow out. The elbow is spongy and really inflamed. He doesn’t splint those but has them stretch. More often, because they can’t use their arm, he will go ahead and give them a half dose of cortisone just to cool everything down.

title: Surgical Interventions for Elbow Injuries
content: Antecedent elbow pain or forearm pain is common in middle age in a very active/ fit person. They don’t know what did it but they ruptured their distal biceps and they get a Popeye muscle. The bicep is the primary supinator of the forearm and a secondary elbow flexor. So when people tear their biceps, they don’t lose that much flexion strength, but they lose most of their supination strength. So if they are used to turning screwdrivers, wrenches, surgical instruments, maybe depending on what they do, then it can be really disabling. In the exam, patients will come in and they won’t be in pain but will have a deformity. Alton will pronate them to wrap that tendon kind of around the radius, and then have them pull up, like they’re doing a pronated curl‒ and they scream. You get it just isolated. And then, you test their supination, and they didn’t know that they didn’t have any supination strength. Then you’d test their other side and they can lift you off the table.

title: Tommy John Surgery
content: This is a tear on the medial side from the ligament being subjected to super physiologic torques. Think high-level throwers who are throwing 90+ mph. When the medial collateral ligament (aka ulnar collateral ligament) is subjected to such traction forces, it will rupture. And the way they keep from rupturing, in general, is by steady long-term fitness. Flexor pronator fitness, that’s shoulder strengthening, biceps, triceps, and so forth. By strengthening everything around it, you can protect that ligament. And if you don’t, then it can rupture, because it’s being subjected repetitively over and over and over again year after year to super physiologic loads. When it ruptures‒ instantaneously, they lose 10 miles per hour on their fast ball. They can still throw, but it just immediately downgrades their ability to throw.

title: Advancements in Hand Surgery
content: Prior to this if you had a laceration or war injury, there really wasn’t much you could do for those injuries (especially nerve and blood vessel related). These were not reconstructible, and you would do a lot of amputations. The most significant advancement, since then, has been the the complete hand transplantation. It involves general surgeons, it involves hand surgeons, it involves a huge team to be able to do that. And the results are mixed. As recently as 5 years ago, only a few had been done. Only in the last several years have these teams been built up at larger institutions to be able to handle this. Even then, it’s fraught with peril. You have to have a patient in perfect physiology as any comorbidities greatly decrease the likelihood of success. And it requires a huge investment for the patients themselves. A bilateral hand amputee is usually the one that can qualify for this surgery (as opposed to a single hand amputee), and they have to meet all the physiologic parameters. The hand transplantation is joined at the midpoint of the wrist. At the distal forearm where you’re beyond that transition zone and can link up tendon to tendon. The nerves need to be linked as well.

title: Common Injuries and Surgeries of the Hand and Wrist
content: What fraction of those injuries that require surgical intervention are the result of an acute trauma versus chronic injury (wear and tear)? It varies depending on where you are. There’s plenty of arthritic conditions, of wear and tear conditions (gym work, or getting back into various forms of exercise, or the weekend warrior phenomenon). And those are not dramatic traumatic injuries. And then there are the people that are falling off the scooters and water skiing and dislocating their shoulders, all that spectrum. But the actual acute… something as mundane as cutting avocados, he sees tons of nerve injuries and tendon injuries in the palm. But it’s usually spread pretty evenly between arthritic and sports related ruptures and injuries, and then fractures and dislocations and ruptures due to traumatic events.

title: Anatomy of the Hand
content: There are 3 bones in each finger (except for the thumb, which has 2), so 12+2 = 14 bones. Then you have the next layer, which are the metacarpals, 5 of those. And then the carpal bones in the wrist are 8 small bones. They are are called coalitions where they’re fused together. The wrist owns the one bone that is the hardest to heal in the body, the scaphoid bone. It’s almost all encompassed by cartilage. So there’s only a couple of little areas where tiny blood vessels can get into that bone, and unlike almost all the other bones in our body, we don’t have what we call antegrade flow into that bone (leaving the heart going down through the arteries and the capillaries and going into the bone from point A distally to point B). It goes in retrogrades. So if you crack that bone in the middle (at baseline), it has very little blood supply, and you probably disrupt it. This one generally takes 10-12 weeks to heal (compared to 6 weeks for the average bone).

title: Treatment for Scaphoid Fracture
content: Historically, we treated all of these non-operatively. Then there was an Australian fellow who came up with a really ingenious screw that had two sets of threads on it and they were a different pitch. So when you’d screw it down the middle of the bone and turn it and when it engaged both bones, it would actually compress them together because they were different pitch (called the Herbert screw). And that was a game changer for us, especially for treating athletes. Where do you access this bone operatively? There are different schools of thought. When coming out of training, everybody made a full incision to expose everything (on the underside of the thumb near the base of the thumb and wrist). And you had jigs that you can put those screws down. Now, almost all of these are done via a small, percutaneous incision, and they’ll go either retrograde often or antegrade (working from the top side of the thumb at the base). It’s really a 3D effort to just get it in the right position. Get a central core guide wire down, and then you use a little hand drill to drill out that and then put the screw down over the wire. It’s really great because patients hardly feel that they’ve had any surgery. They heal very quickly, faster. This allows you to start movement earlier so that when it is healed, you already have your movement back so you’re not stiff and needing to do a lot of physical therapy.

title: Importance of Hand Use for Cognitive Development
content: Meaningful hand use is so important for cognitive development and wellbeing. Over 60% of our higher cortical neurons are devoted just to our hand through the homunculus. “We need to keep using our hands to keep our minds vital in whatever form we’re doing”. Some great studies have been done on that to show what’s the effect of just typing at a keyboard. And it doesn’t stimulate our cortex very much at all. Not typing nor texting. But handwriting still does stimulate our brain.

title: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
content: Carpal tunnel syndrome is a condition where the median nerve is compressed as it travels through the wrist at the carpal tunnel. This can cause numbness, tingling, and sometimes pain in the fingers and hand. It is often caused by swelling or inflammation of the tendons that pass through the carpal tunnel. It can be exacerbated by activities that put pressure on the wrist, such as typing or cycling. Pregnant women often experience carpal tunnel syndrome in the third trimester due to swelling and fluid imbalances.

title: Median and Ulnar Nerves
content: The median nerve controls the functions of the palm side of the thumb, index, middle, and usually half of the ring finger. The ulnar nerve supplies almost all the rest of the small muscles of the hand, allowing us to spread our fingers apart, pull our fingers together, and perform other complex movements. The ulnar nerve is more important for grip strength, innervating the pinky and ring finger.

title: Common Hand and Forearm Injuries
content: Common hand injuries can be categorized into acute traumatic events, wear and tear injuries, and degenerative arthritic problems. The most common fracture is the distal radius fracture, which can occur from a fall or direct blow. The ulna can also be fractured, often from a direct blow or in association with a distal radius fracture. Chronic injuries of the hand and wrist that require surgical care often involve tendonitis or tenosynovitis, which are inflammation in the tendon or the synovium, respectively.

title: Grip Strength
content: Grip strength is important for hand function and can be affected by the number of fingers used. Training with fewer fingers can initially result in a decrease in strength, possibly due to the brain's protective response to prevent overstressing the tendons. The pinky and ring finger, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve, are more important for grip strength than the middle finger, forefinger, and thumb, which are under the median nerve distribution.

title: Hand Strength and Carrying Capacity
content: You can engage your forearms much more with your pinky and ring finger. It’s such a force multiplier for our species. It’s an unbelievable asset in our ability to carry things. Other animals (domesticated) can carry a lot on their back, but we can carry our body weight in our hands. When you look at the Vitruvian man and when you look at the standard anatomic position of in medicine, the elbow has a carrying angle built into it to get whatever we’re carrying away from our body so we can carry more. So we have a 12 to 15 degree natural built in, what’s called valgus or away from our bodies to give us more area to carry heavy things with.

title: Types of Arthritis in Hands
content: There are 2 types of arthritis in the hands. 1 – Rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune form of arthritis that impedes function and physically deforms the fingers in the joints. 2 – Common osteoarthritis, more of a wear and tear problem. It’s doesn’t have an autoimmune component. Currently, there is so much more medical therapy available for rheumatoid arthritis patients. The biologics are amazing, an absolute game changes in keeping people normal for a long time.

title: Arthritis at the Base of the Thumb
content: Arthritis at the base of the thumb is ubiquitous, about 50% of all of us will develop this. It’s a biomechanics problem, there are 6 degrees of freedom. It’s this biconcave saddle joint that in order to come back and forth this way (radial and ulnar deviation), then straight up (palmar abduction), and then rotating around and pronating in order to oppose the thumb tip to the fingertips. It’s doing 3 different directional movements and it just wears out. It’s just subjected to so many odd stresses and it’s unstable like the shoulder.

title: Surgical Procedure for Thumb Arthritis
content: The surgical procedure for thumb arthritis varies depending on what stage they present at, but it’s some form of reconstruction. What we use is basically a reconstruction using your own tissue. Because of the way we evolved, we have so much protective redundancy. We have so many tendons. All of the flexor tendons that flex the fingers also flex the wrists and give a strength. We have multiple tendons that pull the thumb out. They do subtle differences. But we use those for tendon grafts.

title: Trigger Finger
content: Trigger finger is what we were talking about before with inflammation of the tendon sheath. Right in the middle of the hand, there’s a series of pulleys. The point here is that as you’re rubbing constantly going back and forth (whether you’re playing a concerto or you’re rock climbing) and you can get inflamed along that sheath. This particular pulley here is down in the palm (A1), that’s the most common site to have inflammation to where you can even get some nodular swelling in the tendon. And that thickening up of that pulley, then it just actually catches. We call it a trigger finger because it has a feeling like pulling a trigger on a gun. They’re ubiquitous.

title: Emergency Surgery in the Hand
content: One of the few really orthopedic emergencies in the hand, which is tenosynovitis, and then it becomes separative (or infected) with puss in there. I mean, there’s so many nerves in our hand anyway, when you get even a few drops of purulent puss in the finger sheath, it hurts like crazy. And your posture is down like this. You can’t straighten your finger up at all. And it’s exquisitely tender and it looks swollen just along that sheath… It’s an operative emergency.

title: Nerve Pain, Numbness, and Weakness in the Upper Limbs
content: Many people present with numbness, tingling, weakness or pain in the upper limb. It can start from the neck where the nerve roots exit and travel under our collarbone through the brachial plexus in between the scaling muscles and then travels through our armpit and then comes down in through the arm and into the hand. It can be confounding. An example is Parsonage-Turner syndrome (aka brachial neuritis, as in brachial plexus neuritis). It’s uncommon but a fascinating study in that whole process from the neck down. It’s an inflammation of those nerves. We think it’s probably viral related because there’s usually a viral prodrome associated, but it doesn’t have to be. It’s an acute dramatic onset of pain all through here. It is a mixed plexopathy can be in multiple different nerves. It’s a mixed bag of palsy, weakness, and numbness.

title: Shoulder Pain Originating from the Neck
content: Patients often present with shoulder pain that is actually originating from their neck. This can be diagnosed by noting that intrinsic shoulder problems, such as a rotator cuff tear, inflammation, bursitis, etc., usually cause pain that travels down underneath the big deltoid muscle, but almost never goes below the elbow. If pain in the shoulder is going below the elbow, it may be due to a neck issue. Additionally, if someone complains of numbness in the hand and some numbness on the back of the hand, the radial nerve is rarely involved in association with carpal tunnel or cubital tunnel. Patients may also mention that their neck has been stiff. Another condition that can cause this is double crush, where there is pinching of the nerve in the neck, maybe through a disc or a foraminal osteophyte that narrows the canal it passes through. This can render the nerve more susceptible to milder compression down at the carpal tunnel or the cubital tunnel at the elbow.

title: Scapulothoracic Bursitis
content: Scapulothoracic bursitis can occur from lifting weights, especially if you’ve been out of the weight room for a long time, and you go back into it. This can cause a lot of upper trapezius, parascapular, rhomboid type pain from overuse. It is important to do the diagnostic work and talk to the patients and listen to the patients to differentiate this.

title: Nerve Damage from Unstable Fracture
content: An unstable fracture can put tremendous traction on the nerves, potentially causing nerve damage. For example, a patient with a bad shoulder fracture who was put into a sling and told to do pendulum exercises ended up with killed ulnar and median nerves due to the weight of the arm pulling on the unstable fracture. The patient began to lose hand function within 3 weeks of the fracture.

title: Physical Demands of Musicians
content: Musicians are like athletes, doing their craft day in and day out. It’s their livelihood and if it’s disrupted, then both their mental health and their financial health is greatly jeopardized. They are submaximal athletes, but it’s repetitious. For example, in a typical Mozart violin concerto, there are 20,000 bow strokes, and they do that repeatedly over and over again. A lot of these are very unnatural positions. For example, violinists need their hands, their shoulders, they are abducted, they are externally rotated. Their other one is up in the impingement zone. They’re living 8 hours a day doing this, which is terrible for the shoulder.

title: Work at the Musician Treatment Foundation
content: The Musician Treatment Foundation provides free care to under and uninsured professional musicians. In 5+ years now they’ve provided over $2 million in free care. They’ve probably treated around 50 musicians. They’ve had 100’s of non-operative musicians, it’s mind boggling. Often a cortisone shot makes them better.

title: Benefits of Rucking
content: Rucking, or walking with a weighted backpack, can be beneficial for health. It can make one feel lighter, stronger, and better. It can be a game changer for health and fitness.
